title: How to get started with R
text:
What is R?
R is a programming language for statistical computing and data visualization.
  Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R_%28programming_language%29

title: How to get started with R
text:
What is RStudio?
RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) that provides an interface by adding many convenient features and tools.
  Reference: https://www.hertiecodingclub.com/learn/rstudio/install-r-studio/

title: How to get started with R
text:
R vs. RStudio?
At its simplest, R is like a car’s engine while RStudio is like a car’s dashboard.
  Reference: https://moderndive.com/1-getting-started.html#r-rstudio

title: How to get started with R
text:
Installing R and RStudio

Install R by going to R download
Download and install RStudio at RStudio download

title: How to get started with R
text: Getting to know RStudio

title: How to get started with R
text: Basic R

title: How to get started with R
text:
R as a calculator



Addition (+)
Subtraction (-)
Multiplication (*)
Division (/)
Exponentiation (^)




5+5

[1] 10

10-5

[1] 5

20*10

[1] 200

4/2

[1] 2

2^4

[1] 16

title: How to get started with R
text: Your Turn!

title: How to get started with R
text:
Packages


Packages are the heart of R.
Official R package is on the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN)








Reference: https://www.vecteezy.com/png/49657354-a-smartphone-with-colorful-squares-on-it

title: How to get started with R
text:
How to use Packages?
How to install?

You only need to install once on each computer or server.


install.packages("ggplot2")

How to use packages?

Make sure to always load the library before using its functions.


library(ggplot2)

title: How to get started with R
text:
A Function

sample(x = 1:20, size = 2)



[1] 15  2



sample(1:20,2)



[1] 6 9

title: How to get started with R
section: Common data types and how to import
text:
Common data types and how to import
Common types of data files

.csv: Comma-separated


my_csv_data = read.csv("name_of_files.csv")


.txt: Plain text


my_txt_data = read.table("name_of_files.txt",sep = ",")


.xls or xlsx: Microsoft Excel Spreadsheet


install.packages("readxl")
library(readxl)

my_excel_data = read_excel("name_of_files.xlsx")

title: How to get started with R
text:
Your Turn!
Go to this folder: Data
Save these in your working directory, then

Read “score.csv”
Read “score_comma.txt”
Read “score.xlsx”

title: How to get started with R
text:
Basic of dplyr

Reference: https://posit.co/blog/introducing-dplyr/

title: How to get started with R
text:
Prerequisite

The pipe, %>%, comes from the magrittr package (install with tidyverse)
The point of the pipe is to help you write code in a way that is easier to read and understand.
Code should read like a sentence

title: How to get started with R
How to get started with R
text: Reference: https://www.rforecology.com/post/how-to-use-pipes/

title: How to get started with R
text:
The pipe

library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)
# Convert to data frame 
starwars = starwars |> 
  select(name,height,mass,hair_color,skin_color,species)|> 
  as.data.frame()

title: How to get started with R
text:
Dimension of the data



data

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    2    3    4
[2,]    5    6    7    8




data |> dim()

[1] 2 4

dim(data)

[1] 2 4

title: How to get started with R
text:
Cleaning Data
The best solution is… but one simple option is to DROP them.

Count the number of missing values


starwars |> 
  is.na() |> 
  sum()

[1] 43


is the same as

sum(is.na(starwars))

[1] 43

title: How to get started with R
text:
Cleaning Data

Remove the rows with NA values


starwars = starwars |> 
          drop_na()

is the same as

starwars = drop_na(starwars)

title: How to get started with R
text:
Summary of the data

Function: summary()


starwars |> 
  summary()

is the same as

summary(starwars)

     name               height           mass         hair_color       
 Length:51          Min.   : 66.0   Min.   : 15.00   Length:51         
 Class :character   1st Qu.:170.0   1st Qu.: 56.60   Class :character  
 Mode  :character   Median :183.0   Median : 79.00   Mode  :character  
                    Mean   :177.2   Mean   : 77.01                     
                    3rd Qu.:193.0   3rd Qu.: 84.00                     
                    Max.   :234.0   Max.   :159.00                     
  skin_color          species         
 Length:51          Length:51         
 Class :character   Class :character  
 Mode  :character   Mode  :character

title: How to get started with R
section: Summarize the data using specific column
text:
Summarize the data using specific column

Function: summarise()


starwars |> 
  summarise(mean(height))



  mean(height)
1     177.1765



starwars |> 
  summarise(mean_Height = mean(height))



  mean_Height
1    177.1765

title: How to get started with R
text:
Summarizing with specific multiple columns

Function: across()
Action: Apply a function (or functions) across multiple columns


starwars |> 
  summarise(across(c(height,mass),
                   list(sd,mean)))



  height_1 height_2   mass_1   mass_2
1 34.78546 177.1765 29.26981 77.00784

title: How to get started with R
text:
Group by

Function: group_by()
Action: Group by one or more variables


starwars |> 
  group_by(species) |> 
  summarise(n())



# A tibble: 29 × 2
   species   `n()`
   <chr>     <int>
 1 Aleena        1
 2 Besalisk      1
 3 Cerean        1
 4 Clawdite      1
 5 Droid         1
 6 Dug           1
 7 Ewok          1
 8 Geonosian     1
 9 Gungan        2
10 Human        20
# ℹ 19 more rows

title: How to get started with R
text:
Selecting

Function: select()
Action: Select the variables you would like to keep in the dataset


starwars |> 
  select(name, species)

title: How to get started with R
text:
Filtering

Function: filter()
Action: Filter the rows that match the condition you’re looking for


starwars |> 
  filter(species == "Human")



                 name height  mass    hair_color skin_color species
1      Luke Skywalker    172  77.0         blond       fair   Human
2         Darth Vader    202 136.0          none      white   Human
3         Leia Organa    150  49.0         brown      light   Human
4           Owen Lars    178 120.0   brown, grey      light   Human

  select(name,species,height) |> 
  filter(height > 200)

title: How to get started with R
text:
Arrange

Function: arrange()
Action: Order rows using column values


starwars |> 
  arrange(mass) |> 
  select(name, height, mass, species) |> 
  head(6)



                   name height mass        species
1          Ratts Tyerel     79   15         Aleena
2                  Yoda     66   17 Yoda's species
3 Wicket Systri Warrick     88   20           Ewok
4               Sebulba    112   40            Dug
5         Padmé Amidala    185   45          Human
6              Dud Bolt     94   45     Vulptereen



starwars |> 
  arrange(desc(mass)) |> 
  select(name, height, mass, species) |> 
  head(6)



         name height mass    species
1    Grievous    216  159    Kaleesh
2       IG-88    200  140      Droid
3 Darth Vader    202  136      Human
4     Tarfful    234  136    Wookiee
5   Owen Lars    178  120      Human
6       Bossk    190  113 Trandoshan

title: How to get started with R
text:
The pipe
What do you think will happen with the following code?

starwars |> 
  filter(species == "Human") |> 
  arrange(height)

title: How to get started with R
text:
Making new variables

Function: mutate()
Action: Create, modify, and delete columns


starwars |>  
  mutate(BMI = mass / (height / 100)^2) |> 
  select(name,species,height,mass,BMI)

title: How to get started with R
text:
What happened??

starwars |> 
  summarise(mean(BMI))



Error in `summarise()`:
ℹ In argument: `mean(BMI)`.
Caused by error:
! object 'BMI' not found

title: How to get started with R
text:
Assignment operator

starwars = starwars |> 
              mutate(BMI = mass/(height/100)^2)

starwars |> 
  summarise(mean(BMI))



  mean(BMI)
1  24.50539



starwars |> 
  filter(height>200) |> 
  select(name, BMI)



          name      BMI
1  Darth Vader 33.33007
2    Chewbacca 21.54509
3 Roos Tarpals 16.34247
4      Lama Su 16.78076
5     Grievous 34.07922
6      Tarfful 24.83746
7   Tion Medon 18.85192

title: How to get started with R
text:
Your Turn!

Import a new dataset called Scooby-Doo.csv
Does the dataset contain missing values? If it does, drop them.
Which season has the most monsters?
Which season has the highest IMDB score?

Source: The data is from kaggle

title: How to get started with R
text: Beyond our workshop

title: How to get started with R
text:
Head

Function: head()
Action: View the first x rows of the dataset


starwars |> 
  head(3)



            name height mass hair_color skin_color species      BMI
1 Luke Skywalker    172   77      blond       fair   Human 26.02758
2    Darth Vader    202  136       none      white   Human 33.33007
3    Leia Organa    150   49      brown      light   Human 21.77778


is the same as

head(starwars,3)



            name height mass hair_color skin_color species      BMI
1 Luke Skywalker    172   77      blond       fair   Human 26.02758
2    Darth Vader    202  136       none      white   Human 33.33007
3    Leia Organa    150   49      brown      light   Human 21.77778

title: How to get started with R
text:
Top_n

Function: top_n()
Action: Select top (or bottom) n rows (by value)


# Highest value
starwars |> 
  top_n(3, height) |> 
  select(name, species, height)



       name  species height
1 Chewbacca  Wookiee    228
2   Lama Su Kaminoan    229
3   Tarfful  Wookiee    234



# Lowest value
starwars |> 
  top_n(-3,height) |> 
  select(name, species, height)



                   name        species height
1                  Yoda Yoda's species     66
2 Wicket Systri Warrick           Ewok     88
3          Ratts Tyerel         Aleena     79
